Excuse me, but now I'm having difficulties seeing the difference between
using checked exceptions and the Assert class.

Some of us prefer doing

    if(reference == null) throw new NullNotAllowedException() //or whatever

and some prefer doing

   assertNotNull(reference);

The only difference I see is that in the last case you will only have
AssertionFailedErrors thrown. Then someone was talking about using the
assertNotNull (and the other methods in Assert) to "guard for the
unanticipated". But the way I see it, using assertNotNull() or
assertNotEqual() or the like means that you actually HAVE ANTICIPATED that
something might go wrong here. And then I'd prefer throwing a checked
exception instead. There's nothing you can do with the Assert class that you
cannot do in normal code lines too. So, if you think some assertThisOrThat
may guard against the unexpected, well, don't you think you could have
written some if-statements as well, throwing some more saying exceptions
than AssertionFailedException? It sounds to me that the Assert class is used
merely because of "convenience". But, as I said, I don't really see any
difference except whether you catch your own exception or an
AssertionFailedException.

Jakob Jenkov
